On March 1, 1954, while Members gathered on the House Floor for an upcoming vote, three men and one woman entered the visitor’s gallery above the chamber and quietly took their seats. All four belonged to the Puerto Rican Nationalist Party and only hours earlier had traveled from New York City to Washington, DC. The United States had annexed Puerto Rico in 1898, and the island’s relationship with the federal government had long been a point of contention. Some Puerto Ricans sought to maintain their relationship with the mainland, and others, like the four visitors in the House that day, argued for an independent Puerto Rico. The Capitol had few security protocols at the time, and the four Puerto Rican nationalists entered the gallery armed with handguns. Around 2:30 p.m. they indiscriminately opened fire onto the House Floor and unfurled a Puerto Rican flag in a violent act of protest meant to draw attention to their demand for Puerto Rico’s immediate independence. Five Congressmen were wounded in the shooting. Members, House Pages, and police officers quickly helped detain three of the assailants outside the gallery, while the fourth escaped the Capitol and was apprehended later that afternoon. https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/2331

As used in this chapter—
(1)the term “international terrorism” means activities that—
(A)involve violent acts or acts dangerous to human life that are a violation of the criminal laws of the United States or of any State, or that would be a criminal violation if committed within the jurisdiction of the United States or of any State;
(B)appear to be intended—
(i)to intimidate or coerce a civilian population;
(ii)to influence the policy of a government by intimidation or coercion; or
(iii)to affect the conduct of a government by mass destruction, assassination, or kidnapping; and
(C)occur primarily outside the territorial jurisdiction of the United States, or transcend national boundaries in terms of the means by which they are accomplished, the persons they appear intended to intimidate or coerce, or the locale in which their perpetrators operate or seek asylum;
(2)the term “national of the United States” has the meaning given such term in section 101(a)(22) of the Immigration and Nationality Act;
(3)the term “person” means any individual or entity capable of holding a legal or beneficial interest in property;
(4)the term “act of war” means any act occurring in the course of—
(A)declared war;
(B)armed conflict, whether or not war has been declared, between two or more nations; or
(C)armed conflict between military forces of any origin;
(5)the term “domestic terrorism” means activities that—
(A)involve acts dangerous to human life that are a violation of the criminal laws of the United States or of any State;
(B)appear to be intended—
(i)to intimidate or coerce a civilian population;
(ii)to influence the policy of a government by intimidation or coercion; or
(iii)to affect the conduct of a government by mass destruction, assassination, or kidnapping; and
(C)occur primarily within the territorial jurisdiction of the United States; and
(6)the term “military force” does not include any person that—
(A)has been designated as a—
(i)foreign terrorist organization by the Secretary of State under section 219 of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1189); or
(ii)specially designated global terrorist (as such term is defined in section 594.310 of title 31, Code of Federal Regulations) by the Secretary of State or the Secretary of the Treasury; or
(B)has been determined by the court to not be a “military force”.
(Added Pub. L. 102–572, title X, § 1003(a)(3), Oct. 29, 1992, 106 Stat. 4521; amended Pub. L. 107–56, title VIII, § 802(a), Oct. 26, 2001, 115 Stat. 376; Pub. L. 115–253, § 2(a), Oct. 3, 2018, 132 Stat. 3183.)
End text

The base case for the likelihood of an attack of this type is low in any given month.  Right now due to COVID, which makes situations with any sort of large crowd events unlikely, the likelihood decreases further in my estimate. There are few concerts, sporting events, or other public events right now where terrorist groups might hope to inflict mass casualties.  There are very low levels of commuting on subways and trains.  Except for Thanksgiving and Christmas, which have already passed, airline travel is low.  The low level of passengers would make the pay off smaller and the likelihood of detection greater, in the minds of terrorist organization planners.  Terrorist groups like to conduct surveillance of their targets for a number of months and do dry runs to test their plans.  COVID significantly disrupts the terrorist planning and attack cycle.  Our poor ability to get the vaccination program up and running will continue to suppress public events through May, in my estimate.  June through August does not allow much time for target selection, planning, training, dry runs, and everything else that follows in the attack cycle.

Using the same data with a different approach. Start with the uninformative prior: P(CCTA before 2021-Sep-01) ~ Beta(1, 1) = Uniform(0, 1)
We found 8  CCTA in 20 years, use conjugate update rules: a' = a + z
b' = N + b - z Here, z = 8, N = 20, so our new distribution is Beta(1 + 8, 20 + 1 - 8) = Beta(9, 13). For a Beta distribution, the expected value is E[Beta(a, b)] = a / (a+b), so our base rate is 9 / (9 + 13) = 9 / 22 ~ 41% (95% CI: 22% - 62%) Take our observations 2015-present, 1 CCTA in 5 years. z = 1, N = 5. Apply the same update rule to our distribution: a' = 9 + 1 = 10; b' = 5 + 13 - 1 = 17. E[P(CCTA Before 2021-Sep-01)] = 10 / (10 + 17) = 10/27 ~37% (95% CI: 20%-56%). Naive adjustmetn for passage of time: 1 - (1 - p)^365.25 = 0.37037... => p = 0.00126579238186172 We have 285 days until 2021-Sep-01, so we use the same: 1 - (1 - 0.00126579238186172)^285 = 0.303006601455.... = 30%

Based on a 2017 report from The Nation Institute and the Center for Investigative reporting on terror in the US from 2008-16, those eight years included 115 attacks by far-right groups, 63 by Islamist groups, and 19 by left-wing groups, for a total of 197, or just over 2 per month. Many of these were foiled, and less than a third (~25-28% total) resulted in casualties. Based on this, we can expect roughly 20 terror attacks in the US from now to Sep 1 2021, if historical data holds. I don’t think, it will, entirely - while COVID has reduced my estimate of “transnational” terror, a CSIS report indicates that far-right terror was around 66% of attacks in 2019 and ~90% in 2020. Given that that is the primary factor, I would expect the impact of COVID to be minimal, if not an actually positive factor based on it being a divisive issue that has already driven armed confrontation (e.g. armed protestors storming a state house). Add to that the tensions in the US right now and far-right violence seems likely to rise in my estimation. So, from 2 per month in 2008-16, I’m going to ballpark instead 3 per month going forward. This would result in 30 expected attacks between now and the end date of the question. Around a third, historically, had casualties at all - so 10 serious attacks. What are the odds that one of these meets the criteria of a CCTA? A search of UMD’s Global Terrorism Database for 2017-18 (the latest data available) indicates 133 incidents (including unsuccessful) in the US, 20 of which resulted in 3 or more casualties (which I’m using as a rough indicator of CCTA since that would seem to indicate some level of coordination/effectiveness). This would seem to indicate roughly 15% of attacks are successful CCTAs. Based on our estimate of 30 attacks between now and the end-date of the question, this would seem to estimate that 4.5/30 can be expected to be a successful CCTA. Yikes. Admittedly, my methodology is far from conservative; >=3 casualties can easily be a lone person, but on the other hand a CCTA could go wrong (they are complex, after all) and only result in 3 or fewer casualties. Nonetheless, based on this analysis I think the odds are extremely high that the next 10 months see a CCTA.

Piggybacking off the work of @Tinned_Tuna [1] for my own analysis of multiple perpetrator terrorist acts in the U.S. from Jan 1990 to Dec 2019. I chose 1990 as a starting point because it seems like the motivations of many terrorist actors during and before the 1980s bear little resemblance the motivations of most terrorists today. For instance, many of the terrorist attacks of the 1970s and 1980s were committed by Puerto Rican nationalist/separatist groups, Jewish nationalist groups, and Armenian militant groups. By contrast, many of the terrorist attacks since 1990 have been carried out by the now-usual suspects: Jihadist terrorist groups and far-right groups. Multiple perpetrator terrorist attacks that meet inclusion criteria [2] to count as complex coordinated terrorist attacks (CCTAs), Jan 1990-Dec 2019 [3, 4].
— February 26, 1993: World Trade Center bombing...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1993_World_Trade_Center_bombing
— April 19, 1995: Oklahoma City bombing...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oklahoma_City_bombing

— September 11, 2001: September 11 attacks...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/September_11_attacks

— December 8, 2003: Abbeville right-of-way standoff...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_standoff_in_Abbeville,_South_Carolina
— May 20, 2010: 2010 West Memphis police shootings...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_West_Memphis_police_shootings
— December 6, 2011: Killing of Michael Roark and Tiffany York by FEAR...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FEAR_(terrorist_group)
— April 15, 2013: Boston Marathon bombing...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Marathon_bombing
— June 8, 2014: 2014 Las Vegas shootings...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Las_Vegas_shootings
— May 3, 2015: Curtis Culwell Center attack...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curtis_Culwell_Center_attack
— December 2, 2015: San Bernardino attack...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_San_Bernardino_attack
— December 10, 2019: Jersey City shooting...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Jersey_City_shooting (I think @Tinned_Tuna missed this one because it's not yet in the "Terrorism in the United States" Wikipedia page) Base rate: 40%. 13 CCTAs in the past 30 years, 12 of which have occurred in distinct years (two occurred in 2015). 12/30 = 0.4 probability of at least one CCTA in any given year. Inside view: Adjust downward by 10%. Jihadist terrorism has declined since its recent peak in 2015 — "The rise of ISIS has brought an unprecedented surge in terrorism cases ... As the years have passed since the peak of ISIS' influence [circa 2015], the number of terrorism cases has declined." [5] I don't see any immediate basis for another uptick in Jihadist terrorism. There is, however, reason to believe there may be far-left or far-right terrorist activity related to the 2020 presidential election. Scenario planning by the Transition Integrity Project found that "A landslide for Joe Biden resulted in a relatively orderly transfer of power. Every other scenario we looked at involved street-level violence and political crisis."
